title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – In a season often defined by youth and rebuilding, the Houston Rockets were treated to a masterclass in legendary greatness Sunday night. In a 118-91 rout of the Vancouver Grizzlies, Hakeem Olajuwon didn’t just lead his team; he authored a performance for the ages, dropping a mesmerizing 42 points to electrify the Summit.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Olajuwon’s night. The Grizzlies had no answer for "The Dream," whose signature array of dizzying post moves and feathery touch from the perimeter proved utterly unstoppable. He was a one-man offensive system, dismantling the Vancouver defense with a historic efficiency that left the crowd in a sustained state of awe.

While Clyde Drexler provided a solid 18-point supporting role, the night belonged solely to Olajuwon. His dominance in the paint was absolute, forcing the Grizzlies into a desperate and futile defensive scramble. Every double-team was met with a precise pass, and every single-coverage opportunity was a guaranteed two points for the Rockets.

Vancouver, led by a gritty 22 points from Sam Mack and 15 from Pete Chilcutt, simply watched their game plan evaporate under the relentless Olajuwon onslaught. The match was effectively decided by halftime, a testament to one man's transcendent talent.

When the final buzzer sounded, the scoreboard told a story of a decisive team victory. But everyone in the building knew the truth: they had witnessed an individual tour de force. On this night, Hakeem Olajuwon didn't just play basketball; he elevated it, gifting the sport another legendary chapter in his Hall of Fame career.
